newsitem.title: USA: Junk bond new issue downpour to hit U.S. market.
newsitem.headline: Junk bond new issue downpour to hit U.S. market.

text.p: Investors are eagerly awaiting a downpour of junk bond deals scheduled to hit the U.S. market on Thursday, syndicate officials said.
Five separate junk bond offerings, representing roughly $2.3 billion (face value) of new debt are expected to price on Thursday, they noted.

Two of the deals are in the energy sector: TransAmerican Energy Corp's $1.53 billion two-part offering via Jefferies & Co Inc and Snyder Oil Corp's $150 million offering via NationsBanc Capital Markets Inc.

A telecommunications offering is also expected. InterCel Inc, a wireless phone service provider, plans to sell $300 million in debt via Morgan Stanley & Co. Some of the proceeds from the offering will be set aside to guarantee the coupon payment on the notes for the first three years.
Falcon Building Products Inc, a maker of products for residential and commercial construction, plans to sell $245 million in debt via Smith Barney Inc.
The two-part offering will include $145 million in 10-year senior subordinated notes and $100 million in 10-year senior subordinated discount notes.

On Thursday morning, W.R. Carpenter North America Inc sold $105 million in 10-year senior subordinated notes to yield 10.70 percent via CIBC Wood Gundy Securities Corp. The notes are rated B3/B-minus.
W.R. Carpenter manufactures aerial and scissor lifts.
New issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond sector is expected to be light on Thursday, following moderate activity earlier in the week, syndicate officals said.
PECO Energy is expected to issue $50 million in 40-year capital trust securities, non-callable for five years, via Smith Barney Inc, market sources said.
Market sources speculated high-grade corporate bond issuers may stay out of the market until after the release of the closely-watched monthly U.S. employment report on Friday.
